questions.clue: This president issued the Emancipation Proclamation during the American Civil War.
This 1968 tennis player won the Grand Slam and became the first man to win all four major singles titles since the calendar Grand Slam began.
Known as the 'father of microbiology,' this scientist created the first vaccines for rabies and anthrax.
The development of penicillin by this Scottish scientist in 1928 revolutionized the treatment of bacterial infections.
This civil rights leader, known for his 'I Have a Dream' speech, won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964 at the age of 35.
This Italian dish, often topped with tomato sauce and cheese, kicked off a global food phenomenon.
This spicy and creamy Indian dish is commonly associated with cricket fans worldwide.
This dish, made with raw fish and originating from Japan, is so popular that entire restaurants are dedicated to it.
A staple of Mexican street food, these small, soft or hard tortillas are perfect for adventurous food lovers.
Originating from the Basque region, this Spanish method of serving small snacks is a social dining experience.
In 1980, this U.S. team defeated the Soviet Union in an Olympic hockey game known as the 'Miracle on Ice.'
This basketball player famously leapt from the free-throw line to win the 1988 NBA Slam Dunk Contest.
The Chicago Cubs ended their 108-year World Series drought by defeating this team in 2016.
Roger Bannister broke this distance's 4-minute barrier in 1954, a monumental moment in athletics.
In 1969, this New York baseball team achieved their 'Amazin'' win in the World Series, stunning the Baltimore Orioles.
In 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' this man, a hardworking field hand, is wrongly accused of a terrible crime and becomes a symbol of racial injustice.
In 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,' this runaway slave accompanies Huck on his journey and is a symbol of humanity and friendship.
Serving as a stalwart foil to Phileas Fogg, this character in 'Around the World in Eighty Days' provides a humorous mix of loyalty and misadventure.
Often overshadowed by her more famous sister Anne, this character in Jane Austen's 'Persuasion' remains loyal and practical throughout the novel.
This brooding character in Joseph Conrad's 'Under Western Eyes' grapples with loving his country while being caught up in political intrigue.
This chronic and often painful skin disease has no known cure, and is famous for the red, patchy skin it produces.
Named after a Greek mythological figure, this syndrome presents with repetitive movements and tics.
Once known as "consumption", this disease's resurgence is a mystery despite advances in antibiotics.
Named after an exotic dance, this fever saw a mysterious outbreak in New Orleans in the late 19th century.
This medical condition causes athletes to suddenly lose muscle control during their careers, and Lou Gehrig famously suffered from it.

final.clue: Hosting the Summer Games in 2016, this city is the first in South America to host the Olympics, despite a late-year outbreak of the Zika virus, primarily transmitted by a mosquito species that also spreads dengue fever and another STD.
